**Abstract.** In the general setting of a locally compact Abelian group \( G \), the Delsarte extremal problem asks for the supremum of integrals over the collection of continuous positive definite functions \( f : G \to \mathbb{R} \) satisfying \( f(0) = 1 \) and having \( \operatorname{supp} f_+ \subset \Omega \) for some measurable subset \( \Omega \) of finite measure. In this paper, we consider the question of the existence of an extremal function for the Delsarte extremal problem. In particular, we show that there exists an extremal function for the Delsarte problem when \( \Omega \) is closed, extending previously known existence results to a larger class of functions.

The Delsarte problem arose first in the context of discrete codes. Specifically, in [8], P. Delsarte found an upper bound for the number of code words in codes satisfying some prescribed distance condition. The solution was carried out in terms of Krawtchouk polynomials and the MacWilliams transform. Subsequently, in [9], P. Delsarte, J. M. Goethals, and J. J. Seidel considered another instance of the Delsarte problem in the context of spherical codes in \( \mathbb{R}^d \). In particular, they derived an upper bound for certain spherical codes in terms of coefficients of Gegenbauer expansions. Various instances of the Delsarte problem occur in the context of coding theory, see for instance [18] and the references within. It appears in the context of sphere packing where it is used to obtain upper bounds for the density of sphere packings, see [1,2,4,11,12,14–16,19]. For more on the Delsarte problem and its generalisation to locally compact Abelian (LCA) groups, see [3]. Based on the Poisson summation formula, in [6], H. Cohn and N. Elkies use the Delsarte scheme to show that the sphere packing density is bounded above

by the Delsarte constant computed over a class of continuous positive definite functions \( f : \mathbb{R}^d \to \mathbb{R} \) satisfying Delsarte-type problem restrictions. In [19], M. Viazovska showed that the bound obtained by the Delsarte scheme in \( \mathbb{R}^8 \) is exact by constructing an extremal function for the Delsarte problem in that context. So, the problem of the existence of an extremal function for the Delsarte problem seems interesting. In this direction, in [3, 10] the problem of the existence of an extremal function for a Delsarte-type extremal problem is considered for the Gorbachev class, defined as follows. Let \( G \) be a LCA group. Note that we assume LCA groups to be Hausdorff. Consider

\[
\mathcal{G}_G(\Omega, Q) := \{ f \in P_1(G) \cap L^1(G) : \text{supp } f_+ \subset \Omega, \text{ supp } \hat{f} \subset Q \},
\]

where \( \Omega \) is a fixed closed subset of \( G \) of finite Haar measure, \( Q \) is a fixed compact subset of the dual group \( \widehat{G} \) of \( G \), \( \hat{f} \) is the Fourier transform of \( f \), \( P_1(G) \) is the collection of continuous positive definite functions \( f : G \to \mathbb{R} \) satisfying \( f(0) = 1 \), \( f_+ \) is the positive part of \( f \) given by \( f_+(g) := \max\{ f(g), 0 \} \) for all \( g \in G \), and supp \( f \) is the support of \( f \), given by \( \text{supp } f := \{ g \in G : f(g) \neq 0 \} \).

In [10], it is shown that \( \mathcal{G}_G(\Omega, Q) \) contains an extremal function for the Delsarte constant:

\[
\mathcal{D}_G(\Omega, Q) := \sup_{f \in \mathcal{G}_G(\Omega, Q)} \int_G f(g) \, d\lambda_G(g),
\]

where \( \lambda_G \) is a fixed Haar measure on \( G \). Note that this result was also proved in [3] for \( G = \mathbb{R}^d \). In this paper, we remove the condition that supp \( \hat{f} \subset Q \). More precisely, we consider the function class

\[
\mathcal{G}_G(\Omega) := \{ f \in P_1(G) \cap L^1(G) : \text{supp } f_+ \subset \Omega \},
\]

where \( \Omega \) is a closed subset of \( G \) of finite Haar measure, and we show the existence of an extremal function for the Delsarte constant

\[
\mathcal{D}_G(\Omega) := \sup_{f \in \mathcal{G}_G(\Omega)} \int_G f(g) \, d\lambda_G(g).
\]

It may happen that the class \( \mathcal{G}_G(\Omega) \) is empty. This happens when \( 0 \notin \operatorname{int} \Omega \). This is because if \( f \) is positive definite, then \( |f(g)| \leq f(0) \) for all \( g \in G \), and if \( 0 \notin \operatorname{int} \Omega \), then \( f(0) = 0 \), and hence \( f \) is identically 0. In which case, the class \( \mathcal{G}_G(\Omega) \) is empty because \( f(0) = 1 \) can not hold for a continuous positive definite function \( f \) with \( f_+ \) supported in \( \Omega \). On the other hand, if \( \Omega \) is a neighbourhood of 0, i.e., \( 0 \in \operatorname{int} \Omega \), then there is a symmetric neighbourhood \( U \) of 0 such that \( U + U \subset \Omega \). Then the convolution \( 1_U * 1_U \) of the characteristic function \( 1_U \) of \( U \) with itself is a continuous positive definite function supported in \( \Omega \). We can normalise it to obtain a function that

belongs to \( G_G(\Omega) \). In other words, the class \( G_G(\Omega) \) is nonempty if and only if \( \Omega \) is a neighbourhood of 0.

The reader may note that the condition that \( f \in L^1(G) \) is needed in general for extremal problems in various function classes, such as those considered in [3,15]. However, in this case it follows from \( f \in P_1(G) \) together with \( \lambda_G(\Omega) < \infty \).

## 2. Notation and preliminaries

Let \( G \) be a LCA group with identity 0. Let \( C(G) \) be the space of continuous functions on \( G \) to the complex numbers and put on it the topology of uniform convergence on compact sets. The dual group \( \widehat{G} \) of \( G \) consists of continuous homomorphisms of \( G \) to the multiplicative group \( \mathbb{T} = \{ z \in \mathbb{C} : |z| = 1 \} \).
With respect to pointwise operations and the subspace topology that it inherits as a subset of \( C(G) \), \( \widehat{G} \) is a LCA group. Fix a Haar measure \( \lambda_G \) on \( G \) and let \( L^1(G) \) denote the usual Banach space of integrable complex-valued functions on \( G \). The Fourier transform of \( f \in L^1(G) \) is defined by

\[
\widehat{f}(\chi) := \int_G f(g)\overline{\chi(g)}\, d\lambda_G(g) \quad \text{for all } \chi \in \widehat{G}.
\]

The convolution \( f * g \) of functions \( f, g : G \to \mathbb{C} \) is defined by

\[
f * g(x) := \int_G f(y)g(x-y)\, d\lambda_G(y) \quad \text{for all } x \in G,
\]

whenever the integral exists. A function \( f : G \to \mathbb{C} \) is positive definite if the inequality

\[
\sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{j=1}^n c_i \overline{c_j} f(g_i - g_j) \geq 0
\]

holds for all choices of \( n \in \mathbb{N},\, c_i \in \mathbb{C}, \) and \( g_i \in G \). It is a consequence of Bochner's theorem that the Fourier transform of an integrable continuous positive definite function is nonnegative. Consequently, since \( 0 \leq \widehat{f}(0) = \int_G f(g)\, d\lambda_G(g) \), it follows that the integral of an integrable continuous positive definite function is nonnegative. Let \( P(G) \subset C(G) \) denote the collection of continuous positive definite functions on the group \( G \). Define \( P_1(G) := \{ f \in P(G) : f(0) = 1 \} \). Related to the notion of a positive definite function is that of an integrally positive definite function. A function \( f \in L^\infty(G) \) is integrally positive definite if the inequality

\[
\int_G \int_G f(y-x) h(x) \overline{h(y)}\, d\lambda_G(x)\, d\lambda_G(y) \geq 0
\]

holds for all continuous compactly supported functions \( h \) on \( G \). According to [17, Theorem 1.7.3] an integrally positive definite function agrees locally almost everywhere with a continuous positive definite function. When \( G \) is \( \sigma \)-compact, locally almost everywhere is the same as almost everywhere. Therefore, on a \( \sigma \)-compact group an integrally positive definite function agrees almost everywhere with a continuous positive definite function. The approach to the main problem of this paper is to reduce the problem to the case of \( \sigma \)-compact LCA groups and then extend the solution to the general case. Recall that a LCA group \( G \) is \( \sigma \)-compact if it can be written as a countable union of compact sets.

In this section, we show the existence of an extremal function for the Delsarte extremal problem. Our approach follows that of [10]. If \( H \) is a subgroup of a LCA group \( G \) and \( \varphi : H \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) is a function, its trivial extension is the function \( \tilde{\varphi} : G \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \), given by

\[
\tilde{\varphi}(g) :=
\begin{cases}
\varphi(g) & \text{if } g \in H, \\
0 & \text{if } g \in G \setminus H.
\end{cases}
\]

LEMMA 1 (see [10, Lemma 6 and proof of Theorem 2]). Let \( H \) be an open subgroup of a LCA group \( G \), and let \( \Omega \) be a subset of \( H \). If a function \( \varphi : H \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) is in \( \mathcal{G}_H(\Omega) \), then its trivial extension \( \tilde{\varphi} : G \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) is in \( \mathcal{G}_G(\Omega) \).

PROOF. Suppose that \( \varphi : H \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) is in \( \mathcal{G}_H(\Omega) \). In particular, \( \varphi \) is continuous, positive definite, has \( \operatorname{supp} \varphi_+ \subset \Omega \), and satisfies \( \varphi(0) = 1 \). Clearly, its trivial extension has \( \operatorname{supp} \tilde{\varphi}_+ \subset \Omega \), and satisfies \( \tilde{\varphi}(0) = 1 \). To see that \( \tilde{\varphi} \) is continuous, note that \( H \), being an open subgroup, is also closed, and hence its complement \( G \setminus H \) is open. Now, \( \tilde{\varphi} \) is continuous at all \( g \in H \) because it coincides with the continuous function \( \varphi : H \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) on the open set \( H \). It is continuous at all \( g \in G \setminus H \) because it is identically 0 on the open set \( G \setminus H \). It is positive definite by [13, Theorem 32.43(a)]. □

We shall also make use of the following lemma.

LEMMA 2. Let \( G \) be a LCA group, and let \( (K_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \) be a sequence of \( \sigma \)-compact subsets of \( G \). The group \( H \) generated by the union \( \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb{N}} K_n \) is \( \sigma \)-compact. Furthermore, if at least one of the \( K_n \)'s has non-empty interior, then \( H \) is open.

Lemma 2 is standard and the interested reader may consult the proof of [7, Proposition 1.2.1(c)].

THEOREM 3. Let G be a LCA group, and Ω a subset of G of finite Haar measure. There is an open σ-compact subgroup H of G containing Ω such that

(1)  \( D_G(\Omega) = D_H(\Omega) \).

PROOF. By outer regularity of the Haar measure on G, there is an open identity neighbourhood U in G containing Ω with \( \lambda_G(U) < \infty \). We claim that U lies in an open σ-compact subgroup. To see this, let K be some σ-compact open subgroup of G. One may always obtain such a K by considering a relatively compact symmetric identity neighbourhood V and observing that the union

\( K := \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} nV \)

is an open σ-compact subgroup. Now, note that G is a disjoint union of cosets g + K of K with g running through a set of coset representatives of K. Since the cosets of K are disjoint and cover G, the collection of subsets (g + K) ∩ U of U as g runs through the set of coset representatives of K are disjoint and their union is U. Now, either (g + K) ∩ U = ∅ or \( \lambda_G((g + K) \cap U) > 0 \) because (g + K) ∩ U is open, and every open set is either empty or has strictly positive measure. Hence (g + K) ∩ U ≠ ∅ for at most countably many cosets g + K of K, otherwise this would contradict the finiteness of the Haar measure of U. Clearly, U is contained in the subgroup generated by the union of K and the at most countably many open σ-compact cosets g + K of K that meet U nontrivially. Denote this subgroup by H and observe that it is open and σ-compact by Lemma 2. Equip H with Haar measure \( \lambda_H := \lambda_G|_H \). By construction, Ω ⊂ H.

Let us first consider the case when 0 ∉ int Ω. Then, both \( \mathcal{G}_G(\Omega) \) and \( \mathcal{G}_H(\Omega) \) are empty. Therefore, both sides of (1) are equal to 0, and the theorem is proved in this case. Now assume that 0 ∈ int Ω, so that both \( \mathcal{G}_G(\Omega) \) and \( \mathcal{G}_H(\Omega) \) are nonempty.

First, let \( (f_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \) be a \( D_G(\Omega) \)-extremal sequence in \( \mathcal{G}_G(\Omega) \) such that

\[
\int_G f_n(g) d\lambda_G(g) \geq D_G(\Omega) - \frac{1}{n} \quad \text{for all } n \in \mathbb{N}.
\]

Let \( f_n|_H : H \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) denote the restriction of \( f_n \) to H. Observe that for all n ∈ ℕ, we have

(2)  \(
\int_G f_n(g) d\lambda_G(g) = \int_H f_n(g) d\lambda_G(g) + \int_{G \setminus H} f_n(g) d\lambda_G(g),
\)

and since supp(f_n)_+ is contained in H, we have that f_n(g) ≤ 0 for all g ∈ G\H. Therefore, 

(3)  ∫_{G\H} f_n(g) dλ_G(g) ≤ 0.

From (2) and (3) it follows that

(4)  ∫_H f_n|_H(g) dλ_H(g) = ∫_H f_n(g) dλ_G(g) ≥ ∫_G f_n(g) dλ_G(g).

Now, by the definition of D_H(Ω) and inequality (4), we have

D_H(Ω) ≥ ∫_H f_n|_H(g) dλ_H(g) ≥ ∫_G f_n(g) dλ_G(g) ≥ D_G(Ω) - 1/n.

Thus D_H(Ω) ≥ D_G(Ω).

Now, let (h_n)_{n∈N} be a D_H(Ω)-extremal sequence in G_H(Ω) such that

∫_H h_n(g) dλ_H(g) ≥ D_H(Ω) - 1/n for all n ∈ ℕ.

By Lemma 1, the sequence (h̃_n)_{n∈N} of trivial extensions is in G_G(Ω), and since h̃_n vanishes outside of H, we have that for all n ∈ ℕ,

D_G(Ω) ≥ ∫_G h̃_n(g) dλ_G(g) = ∫_H h_n(g) dλ_H(g) ≥ D_H(Ω) - 1/n.

Thus, D_G(Ω) ≥ D_H(Ω), and hence D_G(Ω) = D_H(Ω), as required. □

Next, we show the existence of an extremal function for the Delsarte extremal problem on LCA groups. We first obtain a solution in the context of σ-compact groups and later extend it to the general case. The reader should note that the condition that Ω is closed kicks in here. We also give some information on how well the extremal function can be approximated, which needs some preliminary results.

LEMMA 4 [17, Theorem 1.4.3]. Let G be a LCA group and f a continuous positive definite function on G. Let V be a symmetric neighborhood of 0 with compact closure and set χ := 1_V/λ_G(V) where 1_V is the characteristic function of V. Then the inequality

|f(x) - f * χ(x)|^2 ≤ 2f(0)λ_G(V)^{-1} ∫_V (f(0) - Re f(g)) dλ_G(g)

holds for all x ∈ G.

In the following, we adapt [17, Lemma 1.5.1, Theorem 1.5.2] to our context, replacing weak* convergence against \( L^1(G) \) and boundedness in \( L^\infty(G) \) by weak convergence and boundedness in \( L^2(G) \) to prove essentially the same results as in [17, Lemma 1.5.1, Theorem 1.5.2]. The proofs are essentially the same, but we include them here for completeness.

LEMMA 5 (compare [17, Lemma 1.5.1]). Let \( G \) be a LCA group. Let \( k \in L^2(G) \), and let \( (\varphi_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \) be a sequence in \( L^2(G) \) with \( \|\varphi_n\|_{L^2(G)} \leq C \) for all \( n \in \mathbb{N} \). If the sequence \( (\varphi_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \) converges weakly in \( L^2(G) \) to a function \( \varphi \in L^2(G) \), then the sequence \( (k * \varphi_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \) converges to \( k * \varphi \) uniformly on the compact subsets of \( G \).

PROOF. For \( h \in L^2(G) \), define
\[
L(h) := \int_G h(g)\varphi(-g) \, d\lambda_G(g), \quad L_n(h) := \int_G h(g)\varphi_n(-g) \, d\lambda_G(g).
\]
The functionals \( L \) and \( L_n \) are continuous with respect to the norm topology on \( L^2(G) \). By Hölder's inequality, \( |L_n(h)| \leq C\|h\|_{L^2(G)} \) for all \( n \in \mathbb{N} \). Therefore, by the Uniform Boundedness Principle, the family \( \{L_n : n \in \mathbb{N}\} \) is equicontinuous on \( L^2(G) \). Note that weak convergence of \( (\varphi_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \) to \( \varphi \) is equivalent to pointwise convergence of \( L_n \) to \( L \), and that pointwise convergence together with equicontinuity of \( (L_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \) implies that \( (L_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \) converges to \( L \) uniformly on the compact subsets of \( L^2(G) \). Let \( K \) be a compact subset of \( G \). The mapping \( G \ni x \mapsto {}_x k \in L^2(G) \), where \( {}_x k \) denotes the left translate of \( k \) by an element \( x \in G \) and given by \( {}_x k(g) = k(x + g) \) for all \( g \in G \), is continuous and hence the set \( \{{}_x k : x \in K\} \) is compact in the norm topology of \( L^2(G) \). The uniform convergence on \( K \) of \( (k * \varphi_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \) now follows from the equations
\[
k * \varphi_n(x) = \int_G k(x + g)\varphi_n(-g) \, d\lambda_G(g) = L_n({}_x k)
\]
and
\[
k * \varphi(x) = L({}_x k). \quad \Box
\]

THEOREM 6 (compare [17, Theorem 1.5.2]). Let \( G \) be a LCA group. If a sequence \( (f_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \) of continuous positive definite functions on \( G \) converges weakly in \( L^2(G) \) to a continuous positive definite function \( f \) and \( \lim_{n \to \infty} f_n(0) = f(0) \), then this sequence converges to \( f \) uniformly on the compact subsets of \( G \).

PROOF. Let \( K \) be a fixed compact subset of \( G \). For any function \( h \) on \( G \), write \( \|h\|_K := \sup\{|h(g)| : g \in K\} \) and \( \|h\|_\infty := \sup\{|h(g)| : g \in G\} \). We show that
\[
\lim_{n \to \infty} \|f_n - f\|_K = 0.
\]

Let V and χ be as in Lemma 4. We have
\[
\|f_n - f\|_K \leq \|f_n - f_n * \chi\|_\infty + \|f_n * \chi - f * \chi\|_K + \|f * \chi - f\|_\infty.
\]

Now let ε > 0 be arbitrary. By the continuity of f, we can choose V small enough so that

\[
2f(0)\lambda_G(V)^{-1} \int_V (f(0) - \operatorname{Re} f(g))\,d\lambda_G(g) < \frac{\varepsilon^2}{9}.
\]

From Lemma 4, we have

\[
\|f * \chi - f\|_\infty < \frac{\varepsilon}{3}.
\]

Since (f_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}} converges to f weakly in L^2(G) and \(\lim_{n\to\infty} f_n(0) = f(0)\), there exists an N > 0 such that for all \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(n > N\) we have

\[
2f_n(0)\lambda_G(V)^{-1} \int_V (f_n(0) - \operatorname{Re} f_n(g))\,d\lambda_G(g) < \frac{\varepsilon^2}{9}.
\]

Applying Lemma 4 again, we get

\[
\|f_n - f_n * \chi\|_\infty < \frac{\varepsilon}{3}.
\]

By Lemma 5, there exists M > N such that for all \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(n > M\) we have

\[
\|f_n * \chi - f * \chi\|_K < \frac{\varepsilon}{3}.
\]

Altogether, we conclude that \(\|f_n - f\|_K < \varepsilon\) for all \(n > M\), showing that \((f_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}}\) converges uniformly on the compact subset K. □

We present a version of Mazur's lemma. For a subset A of a Banach space E, we denote by conv(A) the convex hull of A.

## LEMMA 7 (Mazur's lemma, see [5, Corollary 3.8 and Exercise 3.4]).
Let E be a Banach space and let \((x_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}}\) be a sequence in E converging to \(x \in E\) weakly. Then there exists a sequence \((y_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}}\) in E such that

\[
y_n \in \operatorname{conv}\left(\bigcup_{i=n}^{\infty} \{x_i\}\right)\quad \text{for all } n \in \mathbb{N},
\]
and \((y_n)_{n\in\mathbb{N}}\) converges strongly to x.

## THEOREM 8.
Let G be a σ-compact LCA group and Ω a closed neighbourhood of 0 with finite Haar measure. Then there exists an extremal function for \(D_G(\Omega)\). Moreover, the extremal function can be approximated uniformly on the compact subsets of G by a \(D_G(\Omega)\)-extremal sequence.

PROOF. Let $(f_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ be a $D_G(\Omega)$-extremal sequence in $\mathcal{G}_G(\Omega)$ chosen such that

\[
\int_G f_n(g)\, d\lambda_G(g) \geq D_G(\Omega) - \frac{1}{n} \quad \text{for all } n \in \mathbb{N}.
\]

Since $\mathcal{G}_G(\Omega)$ is contained in a closed, bounded, and hence a weakly sequentially compact subset of $L^2(G)$, the sequence $(f_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ has a subsequence converging weakly in $L^2(G)$ to some $f \in L^2(G)$. By replacing $(f_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ by this subsequence, we assume that $(f_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ converges weakly in $L^2(G)$ to $f$. Since $\mathcal{G}_G(\Omega)$ is a convex subset of $L^2(G)$, Lemma 7 implies that there is a sequence $(h_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ in $\mathcal{G}_G(\Omega)$ chosen such that $h_n \in \mathrm{conv}(\bigcup_{i=n}^{\infty} f_i)$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$, and converging to $f$ strongly in $L^2(G)$. We claim that the latter sequence is $D_G(\Omega)$-extremal. First note that by the extremality of $(f_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$, we have that for any $\varepsilon>0$ there exists an $N \in \mathbb{N}$ such that for all $n > N$ it holds that

\[
\left| \int_G f_n(g) d\lambda_G(g) - D_G(\Omega) \right| < \varepsilon.
\]

Now, write $h_n = \sum_{k=n}^{\infty} c_k^n f_k$, where $c_k^n \geq 0$, $\sum_{k=n}^{\infty} c_k^n = 1$, and $c_k^n = 0$ for all but finitely many $k \geq n$. Then for any $n > N$, we have

\[
\left| \int_G h_n(g) d\lambda_G(g) - D_G(\Omega) \right| \leq \sum_{k=n}^{\infty} c_k^n \left| \int_G f_k(g) d\lambda_G(g) - D_G(\Omega) \right| < \sum_{k=n}^{\infty} c_k^n \varepsilon = \varepsilon.
\]

Therefore $(h_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ is $D_G(\Omega)$-extremal. So, replacing, if necessary, the sequence $(f_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ by this new sequence $(h_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$, assume that $(f_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ converges to $f$ strongly in $L^2(G)$. By passing to a pointwise almost everywhere convergent subsequence, assume that $(f_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ converges to $f$ pointwise almost everywhere. The fact that $|f_n(g)| \leq 1$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$, $g \in G$, and that $(f_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ converges almost everywhere to $f$ implies that $f$ is bounded in $L^{\infty}(G)$ by 1.

Since $(f_n)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ converges weakly in $L^2(G)$ to $f$, it follows that $f$ is integrally positive definite. The function $f$ being integrally positive definite and $G$ being $\sigma$-compact implies that $f$ agrees almost everywhere with a continuous positive definite function. Thus, by correcting $f$ on a set of Haar measure zero, thus not changing the value of its integral, assume that $f$ is a continuous positive definite function. Continuity of $f$ and the fact that $f$ is a pointwise almost everywhere limit of the functions $f_n$, each of which satisfying $\operatorname{supp}(f_n)_+ \subset \Omega$, implies that $\operatorname{supp} f_+ \subset \Omega$. Since $\operatorname{supp} f_+ \subset \Omega$ we have

\[
(5) \quad \int_G f_+(g) d\lambda_G(g) = \int_{\Omega} f_+(g) d\lambda_G(g) \leq \lambda_G(\Omega) < \infty.
\]

On the other hand, by Fatou's lemma

(6)  \[\int_G f_-(g)\,d\lambda_G(g) \leq \liminf_{n\to\infty} \int_G (f_n)_-(g)\,d\lambda_G(g)\]
    \[\leq \liminf_{n\to\infty} \int_G (f_n)_+(g)\,d\lambda_G(g) \leq \lambda_G(\Omega) < \infty,\]

where the second inequality of (6) is obtained using that \(f_n\) being positive definite and integrable implies that

\[
0 \leq \int_G f_n(g)\, d\lambda_G(g) = \int_G (f_n)_+(g)\, d\lambda_G(g) - \int_G (f_n)_-(g)\, d\lambda_G(g).
\]

Together, (5) and (6) imply that

\[
\int_G |f(g)|\, d\lambda_G(g) = \int_G f_+(g)\, d\lambda_G(g) + \int_G f_-(g)\, d\lambda_G(g) < \infty.
\]

Therefore, \(f \in L^1(G)\). Next, we show that \(f \in \mathcal{G}_G(\Omega)\) and that it is extremal. To that end, note that the sequence \(\big((f_n)_+\big)_{n\in\mathbb{N}}\) of the positive parts of the \(f_n\)'s converges pointwise almost everywhere to \(f_+\), and that \((f_n)_+ \leq 1_\Omega\). Therefore, by Lebesgue's dominated convergence theorem and \(\lambda_G(\Omega) < \infty\), we have

= \limsup_{n\to\infty} \int_G \big((f_n)_+(g) - (f_n)_-(g)\big)\,d\lambda_G(g)
\]

\[
= \lim_{n\to\infty} \int_G f_n(g)\,d\lambda_G(g) = D_G(\Omega).
\]

Since \(f\) is continuous, positive definite, integrable, and \(\mathrm{supp}\,f_+ \subset \Omega\) have already been established, to have that \(f \in \mathcal{G}_G(\Omega)\) we only need to show that \(f(0) = 1\). Since

Now, having secured the existence of an extremal function for σ-compact groups, we extend the solution to general LCA groups to prove our main result.

THEOREM 9. Let G be a LCA group and Ω a closed neighbourhood of 0 with finite Haar measure. There exists an extremal function for D_G(Ω). Moreover, the extremal function can be approximated uniformly on the compact subsets of G by a D_G(Ω)-extremal sequence.

PROOF. On account of Theorem 3, let H be an open σ-compact subgroup of G containing Ω such that D_G(Ω) = D_H(Ω). By Theorem 8, there exists an extremal function f ∈ 𝒢_H(Ω) such that

∫_H f(g) dλ_H(g) = D_H(Ω).

Let f̃ be the trivial extension of f. By Lemma 1, f̃ ∈ 𝒢_G(Ω). We claim that f̃ is an extremal function for D_G(Ω). Indeed,

∫_G f̃(g) dλ_G(g) = ∫_H f(g) dλ_H(g) = D_H(Ω) = D_G(Ω).

As in Theorem 8, (f_n)_{n∈ℕ} converges to f uniformly on the compact subsets of H, and hence (f̃_n)_{n∈ℕ} converges to f̃ uniformly on the compact subsets of G. □
